Barry Thomas wrote:
>> Note that the scratches on habaki nearly always
>> end in a "burr" which is hammered flat and forms
>> part of the decoration.

and Peter Bleed replied:
> Forgive a technical note. I happen to have seen
> Hagawa-san making "cat scratches"...
> ...the marks are made with a special tool...

I have never thought much about the techniques of making habaki (having
simply
admired great work), so this is an interesting observation of Peter's.
This
would make a habaki where the whole surface is covered with short
excusions
ending in a "burr" - like some cruder WW2 gunto habaki I have seen, but
the
"burrs" are plainly put in individually rather than with a
multiple-toothed
tool.  However, I'm sure there are many different techniques for making
the
nekogaki/amegaki.  I had in mind those where the "burr" clearly occurs
at the
end of a longer excursion or cut made (I guess) with a burin-like
instrument,
hence the "burrs" are rather sparse in number compared to the technique
Pete
described.  Interestingly, the solid silver habaki on Showa period
Gassan swords
has a pattern of "burrs" in a repeated square arrangement.  I could put
up an
image if any one wants to see it.

Barry Thomas.
